item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: Assassin for Escobar Released
item.description: A man who confessed to hundreds of murders as the lead assassin for the drug kingpin Pablo Escobar has been freed from a maximum-security prison under heavy police guard.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 3 McDonald’s Shut for 90 Days
item.description: Russian courts ordered three McDonald’s restaurants in Moscow shuttered for the maximum period of 90 days over sanitary code violations, Russian news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Helen Bamber, Therapist to Torture Victims, Dies at 89
item.description: Ms. Bamber’s method involved revisiting victims’ worst horrors and letting her clients work them out.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Helen Bamber, before the New York showing in 2009 of the art installation “Journey,” which depicts human trafficking.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Likely Premier Is Party Leader
item.description: Ahmet Davutoglu was elected leader of the governing Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., on Wednesday, ahead of his expected appointment as prime minister on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: 173 Victims Identified From DNA Found in Flight Wreckage
item.description: Experts working to identify the victims of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 say they have positively identified 173 of them from DNA samples.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Israel’s South, Families Worry About the Future of Settlements Near Gaza
item.description: This latest Gaza conflict, the third in less than six years, has led some parents to question whether they want to continue living near the border.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A girl from Kibbutz Nahal Oz played in a paddle pool in Urim, which is a short drive away but out of mortar range.

item.title: Iran Altering Reactor in Bid for Nuclear Deal
item.description: The nation’s top nuclear official said the reactor would be redesigned to limit the amount of plutonium it could produce.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Hamid Foroutan/Iranian Students News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Iran’s nuclear reactor in Arak, about 150 miles southwest of Tehran, is being redesigned.

item.title: Skirmishes Put Feeling of Wartime on India-Pakistan Border
item.description: The nightly sounds of artillery fire have become common for the first time since the two countries agreed to a cease-fire in 2003.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muhammad Shadeen at home in Jora Farm, India, where his son and grandson died when a mortar round shot from Pakistan landed outside the house.

item.title: Army Know-How Seen as Factor in ISIS Successes
item.description: As fighters continue to seize territory, ISIS has built an effective management structure of mostly middle-aged Iraqis, including many military officers under Saddam Hussein.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Ukraine Reports Russian Invasion on a New Front
item.description: Tanks, artillery and infantry have crossed from Russia into an unbreached part of eastern Ukraine in recent days, in what Ukrainian and Western military officials are calling a stealth invasion.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers regrouped in a defensive position after coming under heavy shelling in Novoazovsk, a border town near Russia in southeastern Ukraine.

item.title: Rio De Janeiro Journal: From a Compound in the Brazilian Hills, Excellence in Math Emerges
item.description: The National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics in Rio is gaining attention as a hidden gem in a country with few world-renowned educational institutions.
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA|ERJ|NYSE
National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Ana Carolina Fernandes for The New York Times
item.media:description: The leafy campus of the National Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: As Truce Holds, Dazed Gazans Get to Work
item.description: Palestinian workers began clearing rubble and repairing damage from Israeli attacks as residents returned home, but some residents of southern Israel remained wary of the cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Palestinian men on Wednesday in the ruins of Shejaiya, an eastern neighborhood of Gaza City and the scene of the heaviest fighting during the seven-week conflict with Israel.

item.title: Proposing New Capital Is Old Idea in Argentina
item.description: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s suggestion to consider making Santiago del Estero the nation’s capital reflects longstanding tension between Buenos Aires and Argentina’s provinces.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Poisoning of Africa’s Vultures
item.description: The circling scavengers are the poachers’ worst enemy.
item.dc:creator: By DARCY L. OGADA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Dethrone ‘King Dollar’
item.description: America can’t afford to maintain the world’s reserve currency.
item.dc:creator: By JARED BERNSTEIN

item.title: Open Source: Video of Combat in Eastern Ukraine Adds to Worries in Kiev
item.description: Hundreds of Ukrainians rallied in Kiev to demand that reinforcements be sent to rescue besieged fighters in the east of the country.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: W.H.O. Moves Team in Sierra Leone After a Medical Worker Contracts Ebola
item.description: A day after announcing a reinvigorated commitment in the country, the World Health Organization said it had removed its Ebola response team after an epidemiologist came down with the virus.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Debate Over Tiananmen Finds Echoes in Germany’s Fascist Past
item.description: A debate over how to understand China’s recent past, spurred by the writing of a German columnist in China, finds echoes in Germany’s efforts to come to terms with its own history.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Army tanks hold positions on an overpass in Beijing on June 6, 1989, two days after the crushing of the Tiananmen Square demonstrations.

item.title: British Police Arrest 2nd Man in Killing of Pakistani Politician
item.description: The arrest came as part of an inquiry into the stabbing death of Imran Farooq, leader of the Muttahida Qaumi Movement, on a London street in 2010.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Heavy Use of Banned Cluster Bombs Reported in Syria
item.description: The Cluster Munition Coalition said the weapons had claimed more casualties in Syria’s civil war than during the denounced deployment of them by Israel in 2006.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cluster munition discovered at Taftanez airbase in Syria after rebels captured the base from government forces last year.

item.title: General Forced to Retire Over Sex Assault Case
item.description: An investigation had concluded that Maj. Gen. Michael T. Harrison, the top Army commander in Japan, did not properly investigate accusations against a colonel.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Unity Government Effort in Doubt as Afghan Candidate Boycotts Election Audit
item.description: American officials hoped to persuade Abdullah Abdullah, who withdrew observers from a United Nations vote audit, to continue talks on a unity government with his rival, Ashraf Ghani.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Afghan election commission workers in Kabul waited on Wednesday to begin auditing votes from the presidential run-off election.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Take Control of Crossing in the Golan
item.description: It was not clear whether the takeover of a crossing point with the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights by an Islamist group that includes the Nusra Front was related to an advance by the rival group ISIS.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the Syrian village of Quneitra on Wednesday, as seen from the Golan Heights, after a battle in which Islamist opposition fighters in Syria took control of the Quneitra crossing point.

item.title: U.S. Captive’s Mother Issues Plea to ISIS
item.description: The mother of Steven Sotloff, a freelance journalist being held by ISIS, broke her silence to appeal directly to the group’s leader in a video obtained by The New York Times.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: Steven J. Sotloff, 31, was abducted last year while covering the conflict in Syria.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: South Africa’s Subprime Crisis
item.description: We largely avoided the 2007 crash but didn't learn from it. Now we're facing our own bailouts.
item.dc:creator: By T. O. MOLEFE
